thread.title: Australia v New Zealand Gabba Test: Usman Khawaja, Joe Burns must be selected, says Andy Bichel
thread.title_full: Australia v New Zealand Gabba Test: Usman Khawaja, Joe Burns must be selected, says Andy Bichel | The Advertiser

author: Robert Craddock
title: Australia v New Zealand Gabba Test: Usman Khawaja, Joe Burns must be selected, says Andy Bichel
text:
FORMER Test selector Andrew Bichel believes Queensland duo Usman Khawaja and Joe Burns have done enough to win cherished Gabba Test starts against New Zealand next week.
The duo have been hovering on the brink of selection but centuries for the Cricket Australia XI against New Zealand in Canberra on the weekend could prove the clinchers.
“I think they will (get in),’’ Bichel said.
WAUGH: time to think pink for game’s future
KIWI DUO: McCullum and Willianson in ominous touch
“They were both selected for the (abandoned) Bangladesh tour, they scored runs for Australia A in India and have been scoring runs consistently.
Misbah-ul-Haq's trick shot 0:43 Play video
Cricket: Pakistan's Misbah-ul-Haq keeps England on their toes with this incredible trick shot
Fox Sports 26 Oct 2015 Sport/Cricket/News “This is the right time for them. Khawaja has done his time and he looks ready. He has had to reinvent himself, come to Queensland and work hard to get back from an injury.’’ Khawaja seems the more likely of the two to play with the No 3 spot seemingly his for the taking.
WILL BURNS AND KHAWAJA PLAY IN THE GABBA TEST? COMMENT BELOW
He has some big voices in his corner such as Ricky Ponting and Steve Waugh who felt Australia dropped him too soon when his nine-Test career was truncated two years ago.
Burns has opened for Australia in 50-over cricket and the selectors must now decide whether he is the man to replace Chris Rogers whose old fashioned grit became a cherished commodity in his 25-Test career.
Burns’ main rival is West Australian Cam Bancroft whose steadiness is considered an ideal replacement for Rogers.
“It is good to see that competition but it would not hurt Cam at all if he missed out,’’ Bichel said.
Joe Burns (R) and Usman Khawaja cross while playing for the CA XI. Source: AFP
“He has been doing reasonably well for Western Australia at the top of the order but Burns has been getting runs as well and is my first choice around those two. “Burns has been in the system for 18 months with Australia A and making his Test debut last season.’’
Burns has a century and three half centuries from his last five bats and is making it difficult for Australia to leave him out.
He also has scores of 58 and 66 in his second and last Test, against India at the SCG in January, innings which seemed certain to land him an Ashes tour berth tour until Adam Voges’ outstanding form surge pipped him on the line.
Voges seems likely to hold his place despite failing when Australia needed him most on the Ashes tour.
Australia’s selectors will view the first two days of day-night, pink ball Sheffield Shield games this week before picking the team.
The side is close to being settled with unfulfilled talent Shaun Marsh one of the few fringe-dwellers capable of making a major play for late consideration if he can post a big score.
